subject: Re: Llan, Loch, Ax and Exam
msgSnippet: Microsoft Windows Version 5.1 (build 2600, xpsp_sp3_gdr.101209-1647 | Service Pack 3). In the meanwhile, pending a solution to the digital font problem, I ve
messageBody:
Microsoft Windows Version 5.1 (build 2600, xpsp_sp3_gdr.101209-1647 |
Service Pack 3).

In the meanwhile, pending a solution to the digital font problem, I've
learned to write all the letters by hand. Took me a while, and in the
process I discovered what I consider the only flaw in Quikscript. The
letter Th-ee and the letter Sh-e look identical except for their
position, the first being on the line, and the second being through the
line. Read has taken the trouble to design the rest so that there's a
clear distinction and it's not easy to mistake one for another, except
in this case, which seems to require absolutely that we use ruled paper
for writing by hand!



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@...>
wrote:
>
> Odd, I use XP when I'm not using Fedora Linux, so I'm of little help
in newer versions of Windows right now. Which version do you run? This
sounds like a good post for my blog, which seems to have found its
purpose in tech issues with Shavian and QS.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" cossyrosario@
wrote:
> >
> > Language relating to Keyboard (Control Panel) us English (U.S.)
> > I don't know where to find the language bar.
> > So I'm still lost!
> > Help!
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@>
wrote:
> > >
> > > Check your language preferences. The layout should be listed with
the available keyboard layouts. You'll have to start using the language
bar (or its counterpart in newer versions of Windows).
> > >
> > > Happy Digitizing!
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario"
<cossyrosario@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > I tried running the .exe file, but nothing happened. When I
tried
> > > > Start>All Programs to see whether the program had been
installed, I
> > > > found nothing.
> > > >
> > > > I'm not a computer expert, but usually have no difficulty in
installing
> > > > programs, and have had no difficulty with the fonts either. So I
don't
> > > > know what the issue is.
> > > >
> > > > Wonder if you can help.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@>
> > > > wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Strange, I remember seeing those when I still used the
substitution
> > > > fonts. If your setup allows it, I personally would recommend
using the
> > > > placeholder Unicode fonts for writing in Quickscript. It makes
mixing
> > > > Orthodox and QS a lot easier and is really nice if you want to
keep your
> > > > digital QS writings around.
> > > > >
> > > > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario"
cossyrosario@
> > > > wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > These are four characters present in the Wikipedia Chart
> > > > > >
> > > >
<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Quickscript_alphabet\
\
> > > > \
> > > > > > _revised_names.png> which I do not find in the Junior
Script font.
> > > > And
> > > > > > apparently not in the King Script font either.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I also don't find Eat, Age and Ash in the Junior Script
font.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > What font, if any, contains them?
> > > > > >
> > > > >
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
